post.author: 강윤정

comment.author: 김경환
comment.content: 비슷한 경우 인거 같은데 혹시 못보셨다면 참고하세요. 여기 이야기로는 mustunderstand tag때문에 생기는 문젠데 .Net인 경우 mustunderstand tag가 default로 true가 되는데 WebSphere에서는 컨트롤 할 수 없다는....-_-;; 그래서 코드에서 고쳐주면 되는데 단 WSE 2.0을 써야 한다네요. http://groups-beta.google.com/group/microsoft.public.dotnet.framework.webservices.enhancements/browse_frm/thread/b21af082ef686c8f/a080e8c7cad8740f?q=%22SOAP+body+is+not+signed%22&_done=%2Fgroups%3Fhl%3Den%26q%3D%22SOAP+body+is+not+signed%22%26&_doneTitle=Back+to+Search&&d#a080e8c7cad8740f

post.content:
Thank you for the reply.
I compared the SOAP messages between the one generated by java client and the other one from .Net client.
The SOAP message coming from .Net client holds the same structure and the same value of the client certificate in encoded way(Base64).
Most of SOAP message structures are almost same between java and .Net client except a few things related to xml naming space definition.
The trouble in testing WebService is the error messages from WebSphere is just too simple - "The body of Soap is not signed" but I bet there are many various reasons for this simple error.
- The server cannot recognize tags related to the digital sign data from .Net - The server cannot identify the reference of the SOAP body so cannot find where to pick up the signature and digest value of the SOAP body. - Simple the server has a bug with WS-Security Interoperability - I am testing this on WebSphere Studio test environment.
I expect if this problem is related to something wrong with certificate, WebSphere should spit out more specific message such as "unknown certificate", "cannot find a certificate or public key of the requested digital sign".
I am trying in some different way of sending the message out now.
post.title: SOAP messages from Java Client and .Net Client
